title: The City of Boston handed residents $2.2M to decide funding. Here’s what they picked.
author: Samantha Genzer
bullets: Boston residents allocated $2.2 million to fund projects for immigration legal defense, food access, and housing stability.
The Participatory Budgeting Initiative saw over 4,800 residents vote on projects between January 15 and February 15.
Mayor Wu emphasized the importance of resident participation in shaping city investments for community benefit across Boston neighborhoods.

title: Someone allegedly struck her ex’s new girlfriend with a car in Newton. Now both women are facing charges.
author: Abby Patkin
bullets: Rosa Sanchez allegedly attempted to kill her ex's new girlfriend, Esneiry Pimentel-Lugo, shortly after Valentine's Day, by hitting her with a car.
Both women faced charges after an altercation in Newton where Sanchez reportedly drove onto the curb, striking Pimentel-Lugo.
Sanchez and Pimentel-Lugo have pleaded not guilty to respective charges of attempted murder and assault, with a court date set for March 23.

title: Two Boston startups join the race to create the next major weight-loss drug
author: Beth Treffeisen
bullets: Vivtex and Novo Nordisk partner to develop oral obesity treatments, with Vivtex set for up to $2.1 billion in royalties.
Nimbus Therapeutics collaborates with Eli Lilly on developing oral obesity drugs, with potential revenues up to $1.3 billion.
The startups utilize AI and advanced tech to enhance drug formulation and delivery for metabolic and other diseases.

title: MBTA police seek woman who allegedly assaulted man on Green Line
author: Samantha Genzer
bullets: MBTA Transit Police seek woman accused of assaulting a 71-year-old man on the Green Line at Prudential station.
The suspect allegedly punched the man and sprayed him with pepper spray during the February 17 incident.
Police request public assistance in identifying the suspect; tips can be reported to 617-222-1050 anonymously.

title: Monson couple in their 70s killed in three-alarm house fire
author: Samantha Genzer
bullets: Linda Lynch, 73, and John Lynch, 75, died in a three-alarm house fire in Monson on Feb. 19.
The fire at 278 Silver St. required assistance from multiple towns and escalated due to limited water supply.
Two Monson police officers were hospitalized for smoke inhalation while attempting to rescue the Lynches.

title: Roman Anthony’s take on Red Sox World Series expectations in 2026
author: Hayden Bird
bullets: Roman Anthony sets high expectations for the Red Sox, aiming for a World Series win in 2026.
Despite the loss of Alex Bregman, Anthony believes the lineup additions strengthen the Red Sox offense.
The Red Sox face 15:1 odds to win the World Series, with six teams ranked ahead of them.

title: ‘Superhero’ runners to sweep through Boston Marathon’s final 17 miles
author: Annie Jonas
bullets: About 100 runners will traverse the final 17 miles of the Boston Marathon in superhero costumes on Saturday.
The SuperHero17 run is organized by CharityTeams and honors its late founder, Susan Hurley, who passed away in November.
Runners will begin at 9 a.m. from Natick VFW, finishing on Newbury Street in Boston, dressed as heroes and quirky characters.

title: Should pajamas be banned at Logan Airport?
author: Kristi Palma
bullets: Tampa International Airport jokingly suggested banning pajamas in a social media post, sparking nationwide attention and discussion.
An airport spokesperson confirmed the pajama ban suggestion was in jest, encouraging travelers to prioritize comfort.
The U.S. Department of Transportation's campaign promotes respectful travel attire amid rising in-flight disruptions.

title: Sullivan’s Castle Island reopens for the 2026 season
author: Katelyn Umholtz
bullets: Sullivan's Castle Island reopens Feb. 27 for its 75th season, offering popular items like hot dogs and raspberry lime Rickeys.
The seasonal stand in South Boston opens annually before spring, with hours starting at 10 a.m. every day.
Sullivan's reopened despite challenges from a recent Nor'easter that covered the area with snow, affecting travel.

title: Court doc: N.H. country club shooter said he chose location to target rich people
author: Abby Patkin
bullets: Hunter Nadeau, 24, is accused of a shooting at Sky Meadow Country Club in Nashua, killing one and wounding two.
Nadeau allegedly targeted wealthy individuals, claiming they weren't helping the poor and was frustrated with elites.
He is charged with multiple counts including first-degree murder and is being held without bail.
